ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Agha Akram (Ali)

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The biggest lesson I learnt from this class is that there is no perfect way of evaluating and studying Environment and Development issues since it is so complex and a lot of different criteria need to be looked at.I hope in the future, the class can offer more insights into how things can be done and, if there are the lack of accuracy and considerations in some of the projects and programs, how can we improve them? are there any more good and successful examples on dealing with those complex issues? Or we can just only remain skeptical forever?!

Doug was extremely responsive to the students, and the class was a good balance of lecture and discussion (although it started too high on the discussion side). Doug did a great job of keeping the discussion flowing between students of fairly diverse academic backgrounds at a reasonably high level.The class projects were well thought out and helped me to better understand the material. Overall, this was one of the best classes I've taken at FES.

This was basically an economics class. But the Professor was avoiding math and econometrics. I understand this because most of the students at FES are not comfortable with econometrics. The class turned out to be too theoretical. May be econometrics and microeconomics should be a prerequisite for this class.

Great background on development economics - might be repetitive for someone who already has an extensive grounding in the material but I found it to be a really enjoyable survey course. Class discussion was probably the best part. Prof. Gollin and Ali were both great and very responsive to students' questions and requests for additional input.

Professor Gollin is a great teacher. One distinctive advantage of his style is that he often asks a question and allows everyone who has something to say to make their comment, which reveals that as a whole we already know the answers. He is also extremely responsive to student questions. The issues discussed were very interesting. Ali was very nice and helpful when approached for help, but he wasn't too involved with interacting with the other students. While Professor Gollin's streamlined slides were effective, maybe some other media would be nice - eg. more guest lectures, field trips, video clips, etc.
This is an excellent class. Very relevant and practical

This was probably one of the most useful and enjoyable classes I've taken at FES. Prof. Gollin is an excellent professor and the subject matter is broad and applicable to much of mine and other students' work.
I really liked the assignments. Final exam was very difficult.
Instructor are really good at lecturing and listening/answering students' inputs
The balance of lecture and discussion;The assignments were more helpful to my learning than those I've done for many other classes
Acquiring a new perspective to view development in the developing world.
The selected readings and topics were all very interesting.
The assignments were very interesting and provided a great way to delve into class material in a practical way.
The professor's exposition, knowledge and contributions to each of the topics discussed was outstanding. Interesting class discussions.
Be exposed to different approaches and practice some things in the assignments.
See above - discussions in class. I also enjoyed the take-home assignments, actually. They were open-ended which let us do some exploring and helped us to apply concepts/themes.
the problem sets and readings

Professor Doug Gollin approaches economic development from an inquisitive point of view. I enjoyed his style of teaching and openness about literature and debates in the field. I also appreciated the time and support he offered to students.

The breadth of material covered was impressive. The course was taught at a level beneficial to people with a heavy economic background and without a heavy economic background. The professor was excellent - perhaps the best I've had thus far at FES.
The pace of the course and the readings. Professor Gollin did an excellent job facilitating class discussion, introducing topics, and having students be responsible for learning the material.
The intervention project! Save the poor people, tell them what to do! bad, bad...

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Offer more solution and positive examples.

Early one, I thought Doug allowed too much discussion, although this balanced out over the course of the term.Having the reading list further in advance would also have been nice, but wasn't a problem for me.
More structured and organized schedule and assignments.

The problem sets weren't very related to the class work.Also, the final exam was really time consuming, and didn't do a great job of testing our knowledge. The first half of the exam, where we summarized two papers, could be done by anyone, whether they were in the class or not.

The Professor should allow in class discussions but he should be on top of it. We spent a lot of time discussing among ourselves, leaving no enough time for the professor. And as I mentioned earlier, most of the class members have no background in economics. Being too democratic may not help in some situations.
It would have been nice to have had better discussions in class, though I realize with the number of students, it would have been difficult.

I did enjoy the assignments (as far as assignments go anyway :) ), but I think they will get a little smoother with time. There were some kinks in the formatting and procedure, especially on the first one. Likewise for syllabus and readings - it would be nice to have a schedule planned out - at least roughly - from the start. All of the changes got hard to keep track of.
While the lectures are very interesting, it would be interesting if there was more discussion that was not so much about the papers that we read. Nevertheless its great.

Being a broad overview of many of the the important concepts and debates in international development and environment, it is sometime difficult to explore issues in-depth. That being said, the course serves its purpose well by providing a broad range of ideas and a wide sampling of important literature on the topics.
I don't see any significant areas of improvement for the class.
It would be nice to have a little bit more help outside of the class to learn about the econometric techniques. Just a bit so we can understand it from the papers.
Better preparation for the final exam. Make sure people know what to expect early on in the semester.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Questions on the assignments, readings and general issues
Both were very available and helpful.

Doug was always happy to meet to discuss course readings or the class projects, whether it was the theoretical underpinnings, or excel manipulations.I did not meet with Ali, but he led sections and certainly seemed open and happy to help students.
Both the professor and the TA made themselves available.
Not much.
Both the instructor and TA were extremely responsive to student questions, very available to assist students, and provided high-quality help.
Both the Instructor and TA offered excellent help and were completely available for all subjects of the class.
Both were always willing to answer questions and help.
See above - both were great. Very available throughout the semester, really open to working with students, kicking ideas around, etc.
Excellent

The availability and quality of help I received from the instructor and TA was excellent. I received help and advice from Professor Gollin more than Ali Akram, but both were excellent at providing support as well as exploring ideas, projects, and debates.

Professor Gollin is always available for assistance and made that clear to everyone. He had a knack for understanding questions he was asked as well as their underlying implications and would provide excellent answers.
THe TA was extremely responsive and helpful. He was very generous with his time and attention and answered questions very thoroughly.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Despite the good work of the instructor, I don't really learn much from the class mainly because it is quite general and a lot of problems we touched upon I already know but I do not really come away from the class knowing the solutions since we have been mostly focusing on what have been done and what are wrong.

As someone interested in natural resource management, development projects obviously play a large role in the field. The course helps you to better understand the strength and weaknesses of the various development paradigms that are commonly proposed. Understanding the assumptions behind each are important in knowing how to deal with proponents and critics.

1. The prerequisite for the course should be econometrics and micro- and macro-economics.2. The TA should come from the econ department. Someone with enough economics training.3. The 8-hours open book final exam sucks. It's not a good idea at all.
I am focusing my studies on natural resource economics and the implications in international development so this course fit perfectly into my program.

I'm not an economist by any means but it's important to get some idea of econ for any environmental management course. I think this was a good survey course that introduced some helpful ideas and sparked some good dialogue on a lot of topics that we could have touched on in much more depth if we had more time - but seeing as we didn't it was a good intro to these ideas.
This is a very pertinent class for those of us interested in policy analysis and design. I think it would be very helpful if there was a prerequisite that people had a statistics background.
The course is an important addition to my degree program, providing a broad introduction to many of the ideas surrounding economic development and environmental issues in developing countries.
I wanted a broad background to development economics for environmental work. This course certainly helped with this.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I want to learn more about how to deal with environment and development issues and how to try to accomplish both in real life.
I wanted to learn the core link between environment and development. Moreover, the role played by developed and developing world in managing environment and its resources.
To gain a better understanding of the development discourse.
Curiosity

In addition to the course subject matter perfectly aligning with my own academic program, I had taken a course with the instructor in the fall semester and had very much enjoyed his teaching style and had come away from the class with substantially increased knowledge of the subject matter.
I wanted some basic grounding in econ. I thought it would help me understand some energy development issues that I had been researching for other work, and the syllabus looked interesting.
The subject is particularly relevant to my academic and professional interests. I also because of the instructor
See Question 15. I was also anxious to have a chance to takea course with Professor Gollin, as his work on agricultural economics is of special interest to me.
Prof. Gollin was recommended by someone who took a class with him in the fall. I am interested in the subject matter, thus I followed the recommendation.
I wanted to learn more about topics from an economic perspective; this course really helped in helping me learn the subject matter - both in terms of breadth and depth.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Not really, I have discussed the reasons above.
Yes, it did. I have learned many concepts from the class.
Yes.
Yes, I feel comfortable discussing the larger development themes with practitioners, and am able to offer critiques of major projects.
Yes.
I am afraid not.
Yes.
Yes, the course gave an excellent view of the link between environment and development through the case analysis and well known theories of development.
Yes! As I said, a good survey/intro, sparked some good conversation about new ideas
YES
The course absolutely live up to my expectations.
Yes
It exceeded them; I looked forward to this class each week.
Exceeded them.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Not really, I have discussed the reasons above.
Yes, i did. The environment development nexus is very complex and there is no single answer to that.
Yes
Yes, see above
Yes.
No. Though I learned something.
Yes.
See above
YES
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was nice that we had the option to work with or not to work with groups. We also got to choose the group we worked in.

The advantage of the group work was that group selection was voluntary. I was able to work with a group which I knew would enhance my learning and improve my overall experience in the class. Because we knew our own strengths, we were able to produce high quality work in an efficient and effective manner. There were no disadvantages to the group work.

I worked in a group with one of the students from the IR school. It was great to have her perspective and the methods that she employed for solving problems. I learned a lot from that project and felt as if we equally contributed.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a basic class on environment and development and explore general issues. If you already have some of the basic course on this topic try to take something more advanced
They should read all readings before the class and participate in the class discussion.

Keep on top of the readings -- most are interesting and you'll get a lot out of reading them. Of course, get started early on the assignments as you will get a lot out of them if you put in the time. They are structured in a way that you can do the bare minimum and still learn, but you can also certainly put in lots of time and get even more out of them.
Keep up to date with the readings-- you'll get a lot more out of class discussions.
Make sure you do the readings!!

Speak up in class! Really engaging in the discussions will help you to learn a lot and get a lot more out of the experience. Also, choose a topic you're really interested in for the assignments, even if you're not focused on econ. It's a good chance to look at your subject area from another perspective.
Do all the readings and start problem sets ahead of time.
Take this class and ask lots of questions.
It you have a development background, this class may be worth auditing. But if you have a background in natural resources, it's a great course on development topics.
Take good notes on class and readings to be better prepared for the final exam.
